div.p: THE greate≈øt ioy, and ≈øweete ‚Ä¢ t comfort, that a man may haue in this worlde, is a louing, kinde, and hone≈øt wife: Contrariwi≈øe, there is no greater plaque, nor torment to his minde then to be matched with an vntoward, wicked, and di≈øhone≈øt Woman. But now to pa≈ø≈øe further in our di≈øcour≈øes, tho≈øe men whom Nature cau≈øeth their Children to be fooles, in my Iudgement hapneth not by the birth, but by the bringing vp, the which is the cau≈øe that many great heads by long practi≈øe, become readie witted. Con≈øider this al≈øo be≈øides, how that many Children peceiuing and knowing very well, them ≈øelues to be thus pampred vp by their Parents, keepe them-≈øelues ≈øo much as they way out of the Du≈øt a Sun: neyther care they for applying their thindes, to any coÃÑmendable thing, nor for to ≈øeeke to get any more Riches or ≈øub≈øtance, then that which their Parents haue with great diligence formerly prouided for them: but here it may be truely ≈øaid of them, that they are not vn-like the Crowe who liveth onely by ≈øuch Fonde as other Bea≈øtes a Cattle do u≈øually leane: & ≈øurely there is no doubt of it, but if that they were meanely lefte by their parents (as many poore mens Children often are) then would they grow to be exceeding prudent & wi≈øe, and then would they be rich & ≈øufficiently able to liue in a Common wealth.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: ¬∂ Herein is ≈øhewed the occa≈øions of the great difference, that oftentimes hapneth betweene the Parents and their Children.

div.p:
BVT now let vs goe forward, to ≈øhew the occa≈øions of the difference betweene the fathers and their children, holding for certaine, that the difference proceedeth from the trade of life the childe is ≈øet too, and therefore I ≈øay, that it is not enough for the father to know wherevnto

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: ¬∂ Of the great wi≈øedome of men, in getting of riches and of the excellencie of many good and learned Mai≈øters, now in this age.

div.p: LET vs now goe a little furder, and con≈øider that tho≈øe which are wi≈øe, the richer they are, the better they will con≈øider with them≈øelues how riches are gotten with trauell, kept with feare, and lo≈øt with griefe: and that he which putteth his tru≈øt in them ≈øhall be deceiued: for the true riches are tho≈øe, which cannot be lo≈øt being once gotten, and therefore wi≈øe fathers will be carefull to bring vp their children in learning, per≈øwading them that they are neuer rich, vntill they be learned.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: ¬∂ Of the euill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of many children, through the imperfections of their Parents.

div.p: VT among≈øt the other occa≈øions of the ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of children, this is one, when the father is careles, to make them in time to rai≈øe them≈øelues from the ground, my meaning is, that the father b√©eing carefull of his ≈øonnes aduauncement, is many times ≈øo curious to ≈øee him in≈øtructed in worldly matters, that forgetting how the beginning of Wi≈øedome, is the feare of God, be taketh no care at all to in≈øtruct him in the Chri≈øtian Fayth: whereof it commeth to pa≈ø≈øe that many vnhappy children trayned vp altogether in worldly a≈øtayres, and depriued of the true light, cannot ≈ø√©e the right way, but runneth into perdition.

But now let vs returne againe to the former occa≈øion of the ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of children, to which may be added this, when the father ≈øetteth before them a ≈øtayned and ≈øpotted gla≈ø≈øe to looke in, that is, when he giueth them ill example, which the Romanes were very circum≈øpect in, who≈øe mode≈øty was ≈øo great, that the father would neuer bathe him≈øelfe in the company of his ≈øonne, for it is counted a great fault in the father, to ≈øuffer him≈øelfe to be ≈ø√©ene naked by his ≈øonne.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.

argument.p: ¬∂ Yf a childe be of neuer ≈øo good a wit, yet for want of good bringing vp, groweth to be ouer-bad, and ba≈øe in conditions: and this oftentimes falleth out, by the cockering of their Parents.

div.head: CHAP. XX.

argument.p: ¬∂ Of the great commendations of ≈øuch parents, as keepe their children in awe, while≈øt they are young.
